moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 f5: What the heck?  I had to look this up.  It's called the Latvian Gambit.  It's "supposed" to be an aggressive but weak opening.  I decide to attack.
moves.3. Bc4 f4 4. Nxe5 Qf6 5. d4 Nh6 6. Nc3 c: I'm a point up, and I have fairly solid deployment in the center.
moves.10... g5: He's solidifying his hold on my kingside, so I make a mental note that I plan to castle queenside eventually.
moves.11. d5: I wanted him to take the pawn so I could play 12.Nxd5, attacking his queen.
moves.13. Qh5+ Nhf7 14. Bb3: I have started getting into the habit of never offering trades unless I really have to, or if I feel it will clear away unwanted clutter.  I in this case, I think my white bishop is much too important.
moves.14... Bg7: He's getting ready to finally castle.  At the same time he's fortifying the a1-h8 diagonal.  All his pieces are arranged along it.  Perhaps I can flank them and sneak up the other side?
moves.16... Kd7 17. Nd5 Qg6 18. Qe2: No trading queens.  If I can bring my queen up the left side I will have a strong attack.
moves.18... Kd8: Vacating the a4-e8 diagonal unpins the pawn, but leaves the king wide open.   I can't, however, see a better move for black.  18...e6 and I play 19.Nc7 forking king and rook.  Any other move and the pawn is still pinned or I get an immediate check on his king.
moves.19. Ba5+ Ke8 20. O-O-O Kf8 21. Nc7 Rb8: Black is preparing to use his control of the a1-h8 diagonal.
moves.22. b3 Qf6: If black moves his knight, I must stop the queen from moving down the diagonal.
